questions.question: A 3-year-old boy is evaluated for short stature. Examination reveals the following findings. Laboratory results indicate low levels of cortisol and ACTH. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in a transcription factor vital for the development of corticotrophs. Which transcription factor mutation is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) T-PIT Explanation: Mutations in the T-PIT gene are specifically associated with the development of corticotropes in the anterior pituitary, leading to ACTH deficiency and resulting in low cortisol levels. Congenital Hypopituitarism refers to the inadequate production of one or more anterior pituitary hormones, mainly GH, due to developmental defects in the pituitary gland. Causes of Congenital Hypopituitarism Developmental causes Pituitary dysplasia (Most Common) Abnormal development of the pituitary gland, which can be aplastic (absent), hypoplastic (underdeveloped), or ectopic (misplaced). Transcription factor defects: Pit-1 (Option D ruled out) : Determines cell-specific expression of growth hormone (GH), prolactin (PRL), and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) in somatotrophs , lactotrophs , and thyrotrophs respectively. Prop-1 (Option A ruled out) : Induces development of somatotropes , lactotrope , thyrotrope and gonadotropes . T-Pit : Development of Corticotrope cells. Cause ACTH deficiency and hypocortisolism HESX1: Septo-optic dysplasia with combined pituitary hormone deficiency LHX3 (Option B ruled out) : Combined pituitary hormone deficiency with cervical spine rigidity. PAX6 & SOX2. Clinical Features GH deficiency Poor growth and short stature in children (Height below the 3rd percentile for age.) Midline Craniofacial Disorders: Abnormalities in midline structures (like the eyes and corpus callosum) can be associated with pituitary dysplasia due to the developmental pathways shared

questions.question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic due to concerns about his growth and appearance. His height is below the 3rd percentile for his age, and the clinician suspects congenital hypopituitarism. Which syndromes are least likely to be associated with his condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Laron Syndrome Explanation: Laron Syndrome is least likely to be associated with congenital hypopituitarism because it involves growth hormone receptor insensitivity, not a deficiency in hormone production. Although it leads to short stature, it is characterized by normal or elevated growth hormone levels, with the defect lying in the receptor rather than in hormone production. Congenital Hypopituitarism refers to the inadequate production of one or more anterior pituitary hormones, mainly Growth hormone, and is due to developmental defects in the pituitary gland. Syndromes associated with Congenital hypopituitarism: Kallmann Syndrome (Option A ruled out) Characterized by the absence of gonadotropin-releasing hormone ( GnRH ) and often associated with anosmia (loss of smell). Prader-Willi Syndrome (Option C ruled out) Involves hypogonadotropic hypogonadism , obesity , and developmental delays due to microdeletions on chromosome 15. Bardet-Biedl Syndrome (Option B ruled out) A rare genetic disorder involving obesity , intellectual disability , and renal abnormalities, along with potential GnRH deficiency. Leptin and Leptin Receptor Mutations Result in obesity and central hypogonadism due to impaired GnRH production Septo-optic dysplasia Congenital disorder involving underdevelopment of the optic nerves and midline brain structures . It is often associated with hypopituitarism, hypogonadism and HESX1 mutations. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2892,2896

questions.question: A 38-year-old female presents with fatigue, abdominal obesity , dry skin, decreased libido, and irregular menstrual cycles. Laboratory tests reveal low cortisol (3 µg/dL) and low ACTH levels. To confirm ACTH deficiency and to assess growth hormone reserve, which investigation is most appropriate?
questions.explanation: for confirming ACTH deficiency , as it evaluates both cortisol response and growth hormone secretion. Investigation of patients with Pituitary disease ACTH Deficiency Short ACTH Stimulation Test : Initial test for ACTH function. Insulin Tolerance Test : The gold standard for diagnosing ACTH deficiency, as it effectively assesses both cortisol and growth hormone responses . It can lead to severe hypoglycemia and should be performed under close medical supervision. In situations where hypoglycemia poses a risk, the rapid ACTH stimulation test is often preferred. It is contraindicated in Ischemic heart disease & Epilepsy . LH/FSH Deficiency Men : Measure random serum testosterone, LH, and FSH. Pre-menopausal Women : Assess menstrual regularity. Post-menopausal Women : Measure random serum LH and FSH (expected FSH > 30 IU/L, LH > 20 IU/L). TSH Deficiency : Serum T4 levels; TSH often detectable in secondary hypothyroidism Growth hormone deficiency Investigate only if considering GH replacement therapy. Stimulation tests for GH: Insulin-Induced Hypoglycemia Arginine (may combine with GHRH) Glucagon Clonidine (in children) Among anterior pituitary hormones GH & ACTH requires provocative tests others are assessed by pituitary function tests Short ACTH Stimulation Test (Option B) evaluates adrenal gland function by administering synthetic ACTH (usually cosyntropin) after measuring the baseline cortisol level. Blood samples are taken at 30 and 60 minutes to measure cortisol levels. A normal response shows a significant increase in cortisol, indicating healthy adrenal function, while a low or absent response may suggest adrenal insufficiency. Low-Dose Dexamethasone Suppression Test (Option C) evaluates the body's response to dexamethasone. The patient takes 1 mg of dexamethasone at bedtime, and a blood sample is collected the next morning to measure cortisol levels. In a healthy individual, dexamethasone suppresses cortisol production, leading to low levels. Lack of suppression may indicate Cushing's syndrome or hypercortisolism. The saline infusion test (Option D) helps diagnose primary hyperaldosteronism by assessing the body's response to an intravenous saline load, particularly aldosterone secretion. In patients with hyperaldosteronism, aldosterone levels remain high despite saline infusion. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2898 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 680 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4722397/

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with enlarged hands, facial changes, and spacing between his lower teeth. Lab results show elevated growth hormone and IGF-1 levels. What is the most common cause of his condition?
questions.explanation: most commonly caused by a Growth hormone-secreting Pituitary adenoma. Acromegaly: Primarily caused by hypersecretion of growth hormone (GH), usually due to a somatotroph adenoma. Acromegaly Causes GH-secreting pituitary adenomas (>1cm-macroadenoma) (Most Common) Mixed mammosomatotroph tumors (25%) (Option A ruled out) Acidophilic stem cell adenomas , which also secrete prolactin (PRL), lead to symptoms such as hypogonadism and galactorrhea. Carcinoid tumor : Excess GNRH production (Option D ruled out) Tumors in the pancreas, ovaries, and lungs: Ectopic GH secretion (Option C ruled out) Clinical features Acral bony overgrowth Frontal bossing Enlarged hands and feet Mandibular enlargement with prognathism Widened spaces between lower incisor teeth. Soft tissue swelling : Increased heel pad thickness (>25mm) Larger shoe and glove sizes Ring tightening Coarse facial features Macroglossia Visceromegaly : particularly cardiomegaly and thyroid enlargement Other symptoms Hyperhidrosis and oily skin Deep voice, Arthropathy, kyphosis and carpal tunnel syndrome, Muscle weakness and atrophy Acanthosis nigricans and skin tags. Complications Cardiomyopathy : Characterized by arrhythmias, left ventricular hypertrophy, decreased diastolic function, and hypertension. Upper airway obstruction : Sleep apnea, caused by laryngeal obstruction and central sleep dysfunction, affects over 60% of patients. Diabetes mellitus : Approximately 25% of patients develop diabetes, as GH antagonizes insulin action. Hypertension Arthritis Obstructive sleep apnea Colon polyps and malignancy , with up to one-third of patients at risk Mass effect by the adenoma, including visual disturbances.

questions.question: A 50-year-old woman presents with symptoms suggestive of acromegaly, including enlarged hands and facial changes. To confirm the diagnosis, which of the following tests is most appropriate to demonstrate the presence of the condition?
questions.explanation: Acromegaly. Investigations in Acromegaly: Screening test: Serum IGF-1 levels (Option A ruled out) Diagnostic test: Oral Glucose Tolerance Test Diagnostic if GH levels do not suppress to below 0.4 µ g/L within 1–2 hours after a 75 g oral glucose load. 20% of patients may demonstrate a paradoxical increase in GH levels following glucose administration. Due to the pulsatile nature of GH secretion, a single random GH measurement (Option B ruled out) is not reliable for diagnosing or ruling out acromegaly and does not correlate with disease severity. Prolactin levels: Elevated in about 25% of patients with acromegaly. MRI head (Option D ruled out): Gadolinium-enhanced MRI is the IOC for tumour localisation Other hormones, including thyroid function tests, gonadotropins, and sex steroids, may be affected due to tumour mass effects. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2912

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with enlarged hands and feet, visual field defects, facial changes, and headaches. MRI reveals findings as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation: compression, headaches due to increased intracranial pressure, and MRI showing a pituitary mass suggest a g rowth hormone-secreting pituitary macroadenoma with mass effect . Transsphenoidal surgical resection is the preferred treatment. Management of Acromegaly Surgical Treatment Transsphenoidal surgical resection is the preferred treatment, especially for those with GH-secreting adenomas. Post-Surgery: Improvement in soft tissue swelling and normalization of GH levels typically occur shortly after surgery IGF-1 levels normalize within 3-4 days. There is a 10% recurrence rate of acromegaly years later, and up to 15% of patients may develop hypopituitarism. Medical therapy Preferred in medical therapy if curative surgery is not feasible or if GH fails to decrease post resection Somatostatin Receptor Ligands (SRLs): (Option B ruled out) Long-acting injectable forms

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman experiences severe postpartum hemorrhage during delivery, requiring a blood transfusion. Two weeks later, she reports fatigue, weight loss, and inability to breastfeed. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation: Sheehan Syndrome: It refers to acute infarction and ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland due to postpartum hemorrhage and subsequent hypovolemic hypotension. It is one of the most common causes of hypopituitarism Sheehan Syndrome Pathology Decrease in anterior pituitary hormones due to ischemic damage of anterior pituitary Initial Symptoms Classic early sign is failed lactation following delivery Varied Symptoms Based on the severity of pituitary damage Severe Hypopituitarism : Early symptoms :lethargy, anorexia, and weight loss soon after delivery. Delayed Symptoms : Secondary amenorrhea, loss of sexual hair, and fatigue may develop weeks to months later. Growth Hormone (GH) deficiency : Often the first hormone to be lost, leading to Hypoglycemia , muscle weakness , and mood swings . Signs of Premature aging: Wrinkling of face ACTH Deficiency: Can cause postural hypotension & worsen hypoglycemia . Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) Deficiency : Results in secondary hypothyroidism . Unlike primary hypothyroidism, frank myxoedema is rare. Approximately I rd may present with hyponatremia , while Central diabetes insipidus is rarely observed. Pituitary adenoma (Option A) is a pituitary gland tumor that causes various hormonal imbalances. However, symptoms typically develop gradually and would not usually present acutely following childbirth or a significant hemorrhage. Preeclampsia (Option C) occurs during pregnancy and is characterized by high blood pressure and protein in the urine. It usually resolves after delivery and does not cause hormonal deficiencies leading to fatigue, weight loss, and inability to breastfeed weeks after childbirth. Simmonds Disease (Option D) is non-obstetric atrophy or destruction of the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland due to conditions like hypertension and sickle cell disease resulting in hypopituitarism, and symptoms appear gradually. Reference: Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 681,682 Speroff’s Clinical Gynecologic Endocrinology And Infertility, 9th Edition, Page 904 https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27405776/

questions.question: Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for a patient with Sheehan syndrome?
questions.explanation: hormone levels, suggests Sheehan Syndrome . The initial management for a patient with suspected Sheehan syndrome, particularly with evidence of adrenal insufficiency, is to start hydrocortisone to replace cortisol. Sheehan syndrome Investigations Brain MRI/CECT A secondary partial or complete empty sella (Primary empty sella syndrome, or arachnoidocele, is a radiologic finding where the sella turcica appears empty due to CSF herniation from the subarachnoid space, compressing and flattening the pituitary gland within it .). Serum findings Growth hormone, Prolactin, ACTH, TSH, LH and FSH ↓ . ADH is normal as the posterior pituitary is typically not affected. Management Hormone Replacement Therapies: Cortisol Replacement: Administer hydrocortisone (Initial treatment) if there is ACTH deficiency. Mineralocorticoid is not typically recommended. (Option C) Thyroid Hormone Replacement: Indication : Levothyroxine (50–150 µ g) should be given once daily. Aim to maintain serum T4 in the upper range of normal. Thyroid hormone (Option A) should not be administered without glucocorticoid therapy in cases of adrenal insufficiency, as this can lead to an adrenal crisis. Sex Hormone Replacement: Recommended for women under 50 years with gonadotropin deficiency and for men to restore sexual function and prevent osteoporosis. Growth Hormone Replacement: Growth hormone (GH) is given via daily subcutaneous injections for children and adolescents with GH deficiency (Option D) Side Effects : The primary side effect is sodium retention, which may present as peripheral oedema or carpal tunnel syndrome GH replacement should start at a low dose, with regular monitoring of serum IGF-1 to assess response. Reference: Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 682 Speroff’s Clinical Gynecologic Endocrinology And Infertility, 9th Edition, Page 904

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of irregular menstrual cycles, galactorrhea, and difficulty conceiving. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum prolactin levels. MRI of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements about the given condition is not true?

options.A: Female-to-Male ratio is approximately 20:1 for microadenomas
options.B: Men generally present with symptoms earlier than women
options.D: Prolactin levels correlate with the size of the tumor

questions.explanation: suggests Prolactinoma , where men often present later with larger tumours due to less obvious signs of hormonal imbalance. Prolactinoma: (M/C functioning pituitary tumor) Prolactinomas are typically microadenomas in pre-menopausal women, as the symptoms of elevated prolactin levels often lead to early diagnosis. Prolactin levels correlate with the size of the tumour (Option D ruled out) Dopamine inhibits the production of prolactin. Classification of Tumors: Microadenomas : Tumors < 1 cm in diameter. Macroadenomas : Tumors greater than 1 cm in diameter & can be locally invasive and compress adjacent structures such as Optic Chaisma , resulting in Bitemporal Hemianopia ) (Option C ruled out) Female-to-male ratio for micro prolactinomas is approximately 20:1 (Option A ruled out) For macroadenomas, the ratio is close to 1:1. Clinical Presentation: Prolactin has inhibitory effects on FSH & LH. Women : Commonly present with amenorrhea, infertility, and galactorrhea. If the tumour extends beyond the sella, visual field defects & mass effects occur. Men : Typically present with impotence, loss of libido, infertility, or signs of central nervous system (CNS) compression, such as headaches and

questions.question: A 40-year-old man presents with erectile dysfunction and galactorrhea. Blood tests confirm elevated prolactin levels and an MRI reveals a macroadenoma. Which of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

options.A: Immediate surgical resection of the tumor
options.D: Start bromocriptine therapy, followed by regular imaging

questions.explanation: (such as cabergoline) is the first-line treatment to reduce prolactin (PRL) levels and shrink the tumor. Diagnosis of Prolactinoma: PRL levels > 200 µ g/L most likely indicates prolactinoma PRL levels below 100 µ g/L may indicate microadenomas MRI Head is recommended for all patients with hyperprolactinemia Shows suprasellar mass. Management: Asymptomatic microadenomas: No treatment if fertility is not desired. Regular monitoring and imaging are recommended. (Option C ruled out) Symptomatic microadenomas: Use dopamine agonists, titrated for optimal PRL suppression. Normal PRL levels do not guarantee tumor shrinkage. Macroadenomas: Perform visual field testing before starting dopamine agonists. Follow-up with MRI and visual field assessments every 6-12 months. Treatment Options: Medical treatment Dopamine Agonists First-line treatment option Cabergoline - long action and better tolerance (Option B) Galactorrhea improves in 90% of patients PRL levels are normal in 80% of patients with microadenomas and 70% with macroprolactinomas. Bromocriptine (Option D ruled out) Shorter action - preferable in women wishing to conceive Side effects may include nausea, mental fogging, nightmares, insomnia, vertigo and postural hypotension Surgery (Option A ruled out) Indication Tumor causing pituitary apoplexy Cases resistant to medical therapy Invasive macroadenomas affecting vision Pregnant woman with clinical features of tumor Mass effect of tumor persisting > 1 month with medical therapy Radiotherapy Reserved for aggressive tumors that do not respond to dopamine agonists or surgery Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2910, 2911 and 2912

questions.question: A 32 year old nulliparous woman comes to the OB-GYN department for investigation of infertility. She also complains of occasional headaches and galactorrhoea. Lab tests and imaging lead to a diagnosis of prolactinoma. If we want to restore fertility in this patient, which of the following is the treatment of choice in this patient?

options.A: Cabergoline therapy till pregnancy is confirmed
options.B: Bromocriptine therapy till pregnancy is confirmed
options.C: Radiotherapy for mass reduction of tumor

questions.explanation: confirmed Treatment of prolactinoma in pregnancy Desire for fertility DOC - Bromocriptine Bromocriptine therapy is initiated to restore fertility It is short-acting and has low teratogenic effects Mechanical contraception should be practiced for the first 3 menstrual cycles after initiation of therapy to allow for conception timing After pregnancy is confirmed - the drug is discontinued, and serial monitoring of prolactin levels Drug may be reintroduced if tumor growth is apparent Visual field defect If the tumor is very large and threatens the vision, surgical decompression may be done Cabergoline therapy (Option A), although it is the first line therapy for prolactinoma, is not preferred in those patients desiring fertility because it is long acting as it has a high affinity for D2-receptors. Radiotherapy for mass reduction of tumor (Option C) is reserved for aggressive tumors that do not respond to dopamine agonists or surgery; thus, it is not recommended for this patient. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Pages 2911 and 2912

questions.question: Which of the following is not true regarding the stalk effect of the pituitary?

options.A: Hyperprolactinemia occurs due to a hypersecreting macroadenoma
options.B: There is reduced secretion of dopamine in the pituitary stalk
options.C: Significant deficiencies in other pituitary hormones are not present
options.D: Prolactin level is usually less than 200 ng/ml

questions.explanation: non-secreting pituitary macroadenoma and not due to a hypersecreting macroadenoma. Compression of the pituitary stalk results in decreased secretion of dopamine in the pituitary stalk, which leads to unopposed prolactin secretion (Option B ruled out) A serum prolactin level below 200 ng/mL can be observed in cases with a "stalk effect". Serum prolactin level above 200 ng/mL typically indicates a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma. (Option D ruled out) There is no significant deficiency in other pituitary hormones (Option C ruled out) Thus, the hormonal profile in the stalk effect GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH normal or ↓ Prolactin ↑ but less than 200 ng/mL Reference: Pituitary Adenoma - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf. Factors Influencing Disconnection Hyperprolactinemia and Reversal of Serum Prolactin after Pituitary Surgery in a Non-Functioning Pituitary Macroadenoma - PMC

questions.question: Match the following pituitary gland disorders with their respective serum hormone levels. Pituitary gland disorder Serum hormone levels 1. Hypopituitarism a) Severe ↓ ACTH and GH, other hormones maybe ↓ or normal 2. Sheehan syndrome b) GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, prolactin, ADH ↓ 3. Pituitary apoplexy c) GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH normal or ↓ ; prolactin ↑ 4. Stalk effect d) GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, prolactin ↓ and ADH normal
questions.explanation: damage in the pituitary gland caused by tumors, surgery, trauma, or genetic conditions. GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, prolactin, ADH ↓ (deficiency varies based on which cells are affected). Sheehan syndrome Postpartum hypopituitarism caused by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe blood loss during childbirth. GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, prolactin ↓ and ADH norma l Pituitary apoplexy A medical emergency involving sudden hemorrhage or infarction in the pituitary gland. Severe ↓ ACTH and GH, other hormones may be ↓ or normal Stalk effect Compression or disruption of the pituitary stalk causing a reduction in hypothalamic inhibition of prolactin, resulting in elevated prolactin levels without other pituitary hormone abnormalities. GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH normal or ↓ , prolactin ↑ Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2898, 2906 Factors Influencing Disconnection Hyperprolactinemia and Reversal of Serum Prolactin after Pituitary Surgery in a Non-Functioning Pituitary Macroadenoma - PMC.

questions.question: A 60-year-old male with a history of pituitary adenoma presents with sudden-onset severe headache, palpitations, excessive sweating, and hypotension. Lab results show severe hypoglycemia, and imaging reveals hemorrhage within the pituitary and deviation of the pituitary stalk. What is the initial management for this patient?
questions.explanation: most likely developed pituitary apoplexy. High-dose IV glucocorticoids are the first-line treatment that addresses adrenal insufficiency, stabilizes blood pressure, and corrects hypoglycemia. Pituitary apoplexy Pathology Acute intra-pituitary hemorrhage resulting in an endocrine emergency It may arise spontaneously in preexisting adenomas, occur postpartum or be associated with conditions like diabetes, hypertension, sickle cell anemia, or acute shock. Severe ↓ ACTH and GH, other hormones maybe ↓ or normal Clinical features Severe headache Central nervous system (CNS) hemorrhage Signs of meningeal irritation Loss of consciousness Bilateral visual changes Ophthalmoplegia (eye muscle paralysis) Hypoglycemia Hypotension Shock Cardiovascular collapse Management High-dose glucocorticoids is the first line of treatment to correct adrenal insufficiency, stabilize blood pressure, and correct hypoglycemia. Patients without evident visual loss or impaired consciousness can be managed conservatively with high-dose glucocorticoids. Urgent surgical decompression: Required for patients with significant or progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness. Monitoring: Visual recovery is inversely correlated with the duration of time after the acute event, so timely intervention is crucial. Urgent surgical decompression (Option A) is not indicated in this patient as he does not have any signs of visual defects, cranial nerve palsy or impaired consciousness. Thus, he can be treated conservatively with medical therapy. IV dextrose administration (Option C) can temporarily address hypoglycemia but it does not address the underlying adrenal insufficiency which is a medical emergency. Glucocorticoids are needed to stabilize adrenal function, after which glucose levels will normalize. Oral hydrocortisone (Option D) is not preferred as this is an acute endocrine emergency, and oral corticosteroids are not fast acting thus only IV forms of corticosteroid are preferred. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2897 and 2898

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is mismatched with its hormonal profile and management with hormone replacement therapy Langerhans cell histiocytosis of pituitary - ADH deficiency present Panhypopituitarism Langerhans cell histiocytosis of pituitary - surgical excision of the lesion deficiency present Langerhans cell histiocytosis of pituitary-thyroid hormone replacement is essential. hormone replacement after Corticosteroids are stabilized Langerhans cell histiocytosis of pituitary - Chemotherapy is systemic involvement present

options.A: Lymphocytic hypophysitis - variable deficiency in pituitary hormone Sheehan syndrome - treated
options.B: Lymphocytic hypophysitis - Glucocorticoid to reduce inflammation Sheehan syndrome -
options.C: Lymphocytic hypophysitis - Glucocorticoid to reduce inflammation Sheehan syndrome - ADH
options.D: Lymphocytic hypophysitis - Surgical excision if vision is affected Sheehan syndrome - Thyroid

questions.explanation: syndrome - ADH deficiency present Langerhans cell histiocytosis of pituitary-thyroid hormone replacement is essential. postpartum ischemic necrosis of the pituitary, commonly presenting with panhypopituitarism An autoimmune inflammation of the pituitary, causing variable hormone deficiencies Infiltration of the pituitary by Langerhans cells Hormone profile Panhypopituitarism, except for ADH Variable deficiencies : often low ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, PRL, ADH deficiency presenting as central diabetes insipidus May have low or normal pituitary hormones depending on the degree of infiltration Treatment Hormone replacement Glucocorticoid replacement to manage adrenal insufficiency. Thyroid hormone replacement after corticosteroids are stabilized. Gonadal hormone replacement Corticosteroids to manage inflammation Hormone replacement as needed for any deficiencies. Surgery only if visual field compromise or other complications arise. Surgical resection of affected mass Chemotherapy may be needed if systemic involvement present Vinblastine Methotrexate-containing regimens Cytarabine Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Pages 2897 and 2907 Sheehan Syndrome - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf Lymphocytic Hypophysitis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430885/

questions.question: Which of the following is the sequence of hormonal supplementation in a patient of Panhypopituitarism → Thyroid hormones → Growth hormone → Sex hormones → thyroid hormone → Sex hormones → Growth hormone → Sex hormones → Glucocorticoids → Growth hormone → Growth hormone → Glucocorticoids → Thyroid hormones
questions.explanation: → thyroid hormone → Sex hormones → Growth hormone → thyroid hormone → Sex hormones → Growth hormone Hormonal therapy for Panhypopituitarism Hormone deficient Hormone replacement ACTH Corticosteroid replacement should be started first to reduce the risk of triggering an adrenal crisis. Hydrocortisone 10-20 mg/day in divided doses Cortisone acetate 15-25 mg/day in divided doses Prednisolone 5 mg/day TSH Thyroid hormone replacement is then added for hypothyroidism L-thyroxine 0.0075 - 0.15 mg/day FSH/LH After thyroid hormone replacement - sex hormone replacement is initiated Males - testosterone Females - estrogen / progesterone / gonadotropins GH Adults - Somatotropin (0.1 - 1.25 mg SC QID) Children - Somatotropin (0.02 - 0.05 mg/kg/day) Vasopressin Intranasal desmopressin (5–20 g BID/day) Oral 300–600 µ g QID Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2899 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430885/ Hypopituitarism - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
